document_metadata.name: Mitophagy links oxidative stress conditions and neurodegenerative diseases

citation.db_name: Mitophagy links oxidative stress conditions and neurodegenerative diseases.

links.evidence: Mitophagy is induced by oxidative stress.

citation.db_name: Mitophagy links oxidative stress conditions and neurodegenerative diseases.

links.evidence: A previous study also showed that oxi- dative stress is one of the most common causes of PD (Gaki and Papavassiliou, 2014).

citation.db_name: Mitophagy links oxidative stress conditions and neurodegenerative diseases.

links.evidence: Mitophagy is a selective form of autophagy that removes dysfunctional mitochondria and their harmful byproducts and oxidative species to help maintain homeostasis.

citation.db_name: Mitophagy links oxidative stress conditions and neurodegenerative diseases.

links.evidence: Mitophagy is a selective form of autophagy that removes dysfunctional mitochondria and their harmful byproducts and oxidative species to help maintain homeostasis.

citation.db_name: Mitophagy links oxidative stress conditions and neurodegenerative diseases.

links.evidence: Mitophagy is a selective form of autophagy that removes dysfunctional mitochondria and their harmful byproducts and oxidative species to help maintain homeostasis.

citation.db_name: Mitophagy links oxidative stress conditions and neurodegenerative diseases.

links.evidence: In general, defects in the formation of autophagosomes cause impaired mitophagy, which causes PARKIN muta- tions that further result in neurodegenerative disorders, such as PD (Figure 3).

citation.db_name: Mitophagy links oxidative stress conditions and neurodegenerative diseases.

links.evidence: In HD, mitochondrial ROS production and oxidation of mitochondrial lipids play important roles in mitophagy (Johri et al., 2013).

citation.db_name: Mitophagy links oxidative stress conditions and neurodegenerative diseases.

links.evidence: In HD, mitochondrial ROS production and oxidation of mitochondrial lipids play important roles in mitophagy (Johri et al., 2013).

citation.db_name: Mitophagy links oxidative stress conditions and neurodegenerative diseases.

links.evidence: It was recently demonstrated that Htt is immense- ly associated with mitophagy by serving as a frame for both sequestosome 1 (SQSTM1/p62) and the autophagy-induc- ing kinase, UNC-51-like kinase-1 (ULK1), supporting the involvement of mutant Htt in these processes (Rui et al., 2015).

citation.db_name: Mitophagy links oxidative stress conditions and neurodegenerative diseases.

links.evidence: An increase in the LC3II macroautophagy marker protein and a decreased amount of phosphorylated mechanistic target of rapamy- cin-positive motor neurons revealed impaired mitophagy related to the loss of motor neurons in ALS (Okamoto et al., 2010).

citation.db_name: Mitophagy links oxidative stress conditions and neurodegenerative diseases.

links.evidence: An increase in the LC3II macroautophagy marker protein and a decreased amount of phosphorylated mechanistic target of rapamy- cin-positive motor neurons revealed impaired mitophagy related to the loss of motor neurons in ALS (Okamoto et al., 2010).

citation.db_name: Mitophagy links oxidative stress conditions and neurodegenerative diseases.

links.evidence: Mitochondrial fission and fusion hamper mitophagic clearance, which may also be affected by mutant SOD1 (Fig- ure 3) (Albers and Beal, 2000).

citation.db_name: Mitophagy links oxidative stress conditions and neurodegenerative diseases.

links.evidence: Direct production of mitochondrial ROS by using a mitochondrial-targeted photosensitizer can also induce mitophagy (Wang et al., 2012).

citation.db_name: Mitophagy links oxidative stress conditions and neurodegenerative diseases.

links.evidence: In PD, the accumulation of α-synucelin in the SN, which results in excessive ROS, eventually impairs the normal mitophagic pathways to regulate the redox balance and ho- meostasis (Gaki and Papavassiliou, 2014).

citation.db_name: Mitophagy links oxidative stress conditions and neurodegenerative diseases.

links.evidence: In HD, mitochondrial ROS production and oxidation of mitochondrial lipids play important roles in mitophagy (Johri et al., 2013).

citation.db_name: Mitophagy links oxidative stress conditions and neurodegenerative diseases.

links.evidence: Based on this review, we conclude that the loss of motor neurons and breakdown of the redox balance cause ALS in which ROS are an important component.

citation.db_name: Mitophagy links oxidative stress conditions and neurodegenerative diseases.

links.evidence: The induction of autophagy results in the recruitment of autophagy-related genes (Atgs) to a particular subcellular location, termed the phagophore assembly site, and nucle- ation of an isolation membrane that forms a cup-shaped structure, termed a phagophore (Figure 1).

citation.db_name: Mitophagy links oxidative stress conditions and neurodegenerative diseases.

links.evidence: Fur- thermore, a correlation between flavin adenine dinucleotide (FAD) and autophagy was currently noted, reporting that autophagy needs functional presenilin (PS-1) for lysosomal maturation, which is altered by Alzheimer-related presenilin 1 (PS-1) mutations (Lee et al., 2010).

citation.db_name: Mitophagy links oxidative stress conditions and neurodegenerative diseases.

links.evidence: The induction of autophagy results in the recruitment of autophagy-related genes (Atgs) to a particular subcellular location, termed the phagophore assembly site, and nucle- ation of an isolation membrane that forms a cup-shaped structure, termed a phagophore (Figure 1).

citation.db_name: Mitophagy links oxidative stress conditions and neurodegenerative diseases.

links.evidence: In the mutant mice, neurons lacked Atg5 or Atg7, and animals experienced con- tinuous neurodegeneration (Koike et al., 2008).

citation.db_name: Mitophagy links oxidative stress conditions and neurodegenerative diseases.

links.evidence: In the mutant mice, neurons lacked Atg5 or Atg7, and animals experienced con- tinuous neurodegeneration (Koike et al., 2008).

citation.db_name: Mitophagy links oxidative stress conditions and neurodegenerative diseases.

links.evidence: According to another experiment, rapamycin, which is involved in au- tophagy induction, conferred protection in animal models of neurodegenerative diseases (Sarkar et al., 2008).

citation.db_name: Mitophagy links oxidative stress conditions and neurodegenerative diseases.

links.evidence: According to another experiment, rapamycin, which is involved in au- tophagy induction, conferred protection in animal models of neurodegenerative diseases (Sarkar et al., 2008).

citation.db_name: Mitophagy links oxidative stress conditions and neurodegenerative diseases.

links.evidence: Apart from these, mechanistic target of rapamycin sequestration causes the aggregation of Huntington protein (Htt), which results in the upregulation of autophagy or polymorphisms in the autophagy-related gene Atg7 that fur- ther causes HD (Barsoum et al., 2006; Jahani-Asl et al., 2007) (Figure 3).

citation.db_name: Mitophagy links oxidative stress conditions and neurodegenerative diseases.

links.evidence: The role of PINK1 has been well-documented in neurodegenerative and aging-related diseases (Li and Hu, 2015).

citation.db_name: Mitophagy links oxidative stress conditions and neurodegenerative diseases.

links.evidence: Additionally, NIX, which is also known as beclin-2 (BCL2)/ adenovirus E1B 19 kDa protein-interacting protein 3-like (BNIP3L), is transcriptionally upregulated in the period of reticulocyte maturation to erythrocytes.

citation.db_name: Mitophagy links oxidative stress conditions and neurodegenerative diseases.

links.evidence: Additionally, NIX, which is also known as beclin-2 (BCL2)/ adenovirus E1B 19 kDa protein-interacting protein 3-like (BNIP3L), is transcriptionally upregulated in the period of reticulocyte maturation to erythrocytes.

citation.db_name: Mitophagy links oxidative stress conditions and neurodegenerative diseases.

links.evidence: NIX/BNIP3L inter- acts directly with LC3B or Golgi-associated ATPase Enhancer of 16 kDa (GATE-16) via an LC3-interacting region (LIR), hence mediating the sequestration of NIX-expressing mito- chondria via the growing phagophore (Novak et al., 2010).

citation.db_name: Mitophagy links oxidative stress conditions and neurodegenerative diseases.

links.evidence: NIX/BNIP3L inter- acts directly with LC3B or Golgi-associated ATPase Enhancer of 16 kDa (GATE-16) via an LC3-interacting region (LIR), hence mediating the sequestration of NIX-expressing mito- chondria via the growing phagophore (Novak et al., 2010).

citation.db_name: Mitophagy links oxidative stress conditions and neurodegenerative diseases.

links.evidence: Motor neu- ron death is caused by the dysfunction of mitochondria by directing them toward calcium-mediated excitotoxicity, by stimulating ROS generation and initiating the intrinsic apop- totic pathway (Julien, 2007).

links.evidence: Motor neu- ron death is caused by the dysfunction of mitochondria by directing them toward calcium-mediated excitotoxicity, by stimulating ROS generation and initiating the intrinsic apop- totic pathway (Julien, 2007).

citation.db_name: Mitophagy links oxidative stress conditions and neurodegenerative diseases.

links.evidence: PINK1 is a mitochondri- al-targeted serine/threonine kinase that plays a protective role against mitochondrial dysfunction and apoptosis with mitochondrial quality control by activating PINK1/PAR- KIN-induced mitophagy (Figure 2) (Fivenson et al., 2017).

citation.db_name: Mitophagy links oxidative stress conditions and neurodegenerative diseases.

links.evidence: PINK1 is a mitochondri- al-targeted serine/threonine kinase that plays a protective role against mitochondrial dysfunction and apoptosis with mitochondrial quality control by activating PINK1/PAR- KIN-induced mitophagy (Figure 2) (Fivenson et al., 2017).

citation.db_name: Mitophagy links oxidative stress conditions and neurodegenerative diseases.

links.evidence: In dopaminergic neurons of the substantia nigra (SN), PD proteins such as Parkin, PINK1, DJ-1, and leucine-rich repeat serine/threonine-protein kinase 2 (LARRK2) as well as α-synucelin, play important roles in preventing cell death by maintaining normal mito- chondrial function, protecting against oxidative stress, me- diating mitophagy, and preventing apoptosis (Mukherjee et al., 2015).

citation.db_name: Mitophagy links oxidative stress conditions and neurodegenerative diseases.

links.evidence: PINK1 is a mitochondri- al-targeted serine/threonine kinase that plays a protective role against mitochondrial dysfunction and apoptosis with mitochondrial quality control by activating PINK1/PAR- KIN-induced mitophagy (Figure 2) (Fivenson et al., 2017).

citation.db_name: Mitophagy links oxidative stress conditions and neurodegenerative diseases.

links.evidence: The ag - gregation of PINK on the mitochondrial surface induces mi- tophagy by volunteering PARKIN to degrade mitochondria via a mechanism that is not completely understood.

citation.db_name: Mitophagy links oxidative stress conditions and neurodegenerative diseases.

links.evidence: The role of PINK1 has been well-documented in neurodegenerative and aging-related diseases (Li and Hu, 2015).

citation.db_name: Mitophagy links oxidative stress conditions and neurodegenerative diseases.

links.evidence: The cytosolic E3 ubiquitin ligase PARKIN and mitochon - drial PINK1 have been implicated in the abnormal expres- sion of genes associated with a recessive form of Parkinson- ism (Schiavi and Ventura, 2014).

citation.db_name: Mitophagy links oxidative stress conditions and neurodegenerative diseases.

links.evidence: Following mitochondrial depolarization, PINK1 is translocated to the inner mitochondrial membrane, degraded, and sustained on the mitochondrial membrane (Lazarou et al., 2012).

citation.db_name: Mitophagy links oxidative stress conditions and neurodegenerative diseases.

links.evidence: Translocation of PARKIN to damaged mitochondria has been shown to weaken PINK1 function (Geisler et al., 2010).

citation.db_name: Mitophagy links oxidative stress conditions and neurodegenerative diseases.

links.evidence: The mitochondrial fusion proteins mitofusion 1 (Mfn1) and mitofusion 2 (Mfn2) have been recognized as substrates of PARKIN (Rakovic et al., 2011), as illustrated in Figure 2.

citation.db_name: Mitophagy links oxidative stress conditions and neurodegenerative diseases.

links.evidence: The mitochondrial fusion proteins mitofusion 1 (Mfn1) and mitofusion 2 (Mfn2) have been recognized as substrates of PARKIN (Rakovic et al., 2011), as illustrated in Figure 2.

citation.db_name: Mitophagy links oxidative stress conditions and neurodegenerative diseases.

links.evidence: PARKIN hinders mitochondrial fusion via the degeneration of mitofusions, thus isolating damaged mitochondria from the healthy mitochondrial membrane proteins, such as the voltage-dependent anion channel (VADC), the mitochondrial RhoGTase (MIRO) 1 (Figure 2) and constituents of the mitochondrial translo- case complex (TOM70, TOM40 and TOM20) (Yoshii et al.,2011).

citation.db_name: Mitophagy links oxidative stress conditions and neurodegenerative diseases.

links.evidence: Using transgenic Drosophila expressing human tau, Iiji- ma-Ando et al. (2012) demonstrated that RNAi-mediated Drosophila Miro (dMiro) knockdown enhanced human tau phosphorylation at the AD-related site Ser262 (phopgo-tau), resulting in enhanced levels of active PAR-1 and increased tau-mediated neurodegeneration.

links.evidence: Various studies have reported dysfunctional Miro in ALS patients or animal models of the disease, including a report of significantly lower levels of Miro1 present in spinal cord samples of ALS patients (Zhang et al., 2015).

citation.db_name: Mitophagy links oxidative stress conditions and neurodegenerative diseases.

links.evidence: Recessive mutations in PINK1 and PARKIN can cause PD and lead to a failure of mitophagy, causing mitochon- drial damage (Kahle et al., 2009) and contributing to disease pathogenesis.

links.evidence: The PD-related protein named Leucine-rich repeat kinase 2 (LRRK2) was recently shown to bind to MIRO1, inducing its degradation.

links.evidence: Various studies have reported dysfunctional Miro in ALS patients or animal models of the disease, including a report of significantly lower levels of Miro1 present in spinal cord samples of ALS patients (Zhang et al., 2015).

citation.db_name: Mitophagy links oxidative stress conditions and neurodegenerative diseases.

links.evidence: Mutant SOD1 has been reported to impart Parkin-dependent degradation of MIRO1, which may explain the mitochondrial trafficking defect (Devine and Kittler, 2018).

citation.db_name: Mitophagy links oxidative stress conditions and neurodegenerative diseases.

links.evidence: The same study also de- scribed Miro1-knockout mice, which exhibited upper motor neuron degeneration (Nguyen et al., 2014).

citation.db_name: Mitophagy links oxidative stress conditions and neurodegenerative diseases.

links.evidence: In general, defects in the formation of autophagosomes cause impaired mitophagy, which causes PARKIN muta- tions that further result in neurodegenerative disorders, such as PD (Figure 3).

citation.db_name: Mitophagy links oxidative stress conditions and neurodegenerative diseases.

links.evidence: In PD, the accumulation of α-synucelin in the SN, which results in excessive ROS, eventually impairs the normal mitophagic pathways to regulate the redox balance and ho- meostasis (Gaki and Papavassiliou, 2014).

citation.db_name: Mitophagy links oxidative stress conditions and neurodegenerative diseases.

links.evidence: In HD, mitochondrial ROS production and oxidation of mitochondrial lipids play important roles in mitophagy (Johri et al., 2013).

citation.db_name: Mitophagy links oxidative stress conditions and neurodegenerative diseases.

links.evidence: In addition, it has been delineated that nitric oxide in- creases mitochondrial fission in neurons, initiating neuronal loss in a mouse model of stroke (Barsoum et al., 2006).

citation.db_name: Mitophagy links oxidative stress conditions and neurodegenerative diseases.

links.evidence: Apart from these, mechanistic target of rapamycin sequestration causes the aggregation of Huntington protein (Htt), which results in the upregulation of autophagy or polymorphisms in the autophagy-related gene Atg7 that fur- ther causes HD (Barsoum et al., 2006; Jahani-Asl et al., 2007) (Figure 3).

citation.db_name: Mitophagy links oxidative stress conditions and neurodegenerative diseases.

links.evidence: It was recently demonstrated that Htt is immense- ly associated with mitophagy by serving as a frame for both sequestosome 1 (SQSTM1/p62) and the autophagy-induc- ing kinase, UNC-51-like kinase-1 (ULK1), supporting the involvement of mutant Htt in these processes (Rui et al., 2015).

citation.db_name: Mitophagy links oxidative stress conditions and neurodegenerative diseases.

links.evidence: An increase in the LC3II macroautophagy marker protein and a decreased amount of phosphorylated mechanistic target of rapamy- cin-positive motor neurons revealed impaired mitophagy related to the loss of motor neurons in ALS (Okamoto et al., 2010).

citation.db_name: Mitophagy links oxidative stress conditions and neurodegenerative diseases.

links.evidence: GSH levels were lower in the motor cortex of ALS patients than those in the control vol- unteers (Weiduschat et al., 2014), and decreased levels of GSH result in neurological deficits and promoted the pro - gression of mitochondrial pathology in the mutant SOD1 ALS mouse model (Vargas et al., 2011).

citation.db_name: Mitophagy links oxidative stress conditions and neurodegenerative diseases.

links.evidence: Based on this review, we conclude that the loss of motor neurons and breakdown of the redox balance cause ALS in which ROS are an important component.

citation.db_name: Mitophagy links oxidative stress conditions and neurodegenerative diseases.

links.evidence: Mitochondrial fission and fusion hamper mitophagic clearance, which may also be affected by mutant SOD1 (Fig- ure 3) (Albers and Beal, 2000).

links.evidence: Mutant SOD1 impairs mitochondrial retrograde axonal transport (Magrané et al., 2013) along with mitochondrial network fragmentation, indicating the induction of mitophagy (Carrì et al., 2017).
